da lä tjakktja ja gillgi-jmä sarva-jd njuovva-t
It is autumn and we will slaughter the reindeer bulls
d-á-n ájte-n ini-mä jáfo-jd ja suhkuri-jd ja gárvo-jd ja iehtjá biebmo-jd
‘In this shed we had flour and sugar and clothing and other food.’
gokt lä d-a-n almatj-a namma ma-jna ságasta
‘What is the name of that person who you are talking with?’
dä virti-v vállde-t giehpa-jd ja ribbre-v ja dagari-jd ulgos
‘Then I have to take out the lungs, the liver and such things.’
‘I give food to all the reindeer.’
‘Yes, and we slept under that for a night.’
‘Some reindeer don’t come into the corral.’
‘You are my maternal uncle.’ (lit.: you are maternal uncle to me)
‘Well, what more did you do in Áhkkabakkte?’
‘The Saami man has a dog.’ (lit.: at Saami is dog)
‘I loosen the stomach from the liver.’
‘I have a headache.’ (lit.: ‘I am from head’)
mån i-v tuhtje d-a-v färska mále-st
‘I don’t like that (made) of fresh blood.’
‘These are sewn out of furless leather.’
‘The hut has been built by children.’
men ådtjo sáme giela-v ságasti-t duv årbeni-j
‘But were you allowed to speak the Saami language with your siblings?’
‘Do you take your coffee with sugar or without sugar?’
del vuodja bijla-jn Örnvika-j ja dä vádnasi-jn Tjeggelvas-a badjel
‘Now one drives to Örnvik by car, then by boat over Lake Tjeggelvas.’
‘Sven is as old as Inger.’ (lit.: Sven is one age with Inger)
‘Do you take your coffee with sugar or without sugar?’
áhttje-s dá lä gähtja-min jus gävdni-j aktak nagin getjok-miesse
‘My father is checking if there are any unmarked calves.’
nå dä huli-j nå hälse-t del mamma-set ja pahpa-set
‘Well then she said “well, say hello to your mother and your father”.’
ja dä li-j mijan sessa Kärin
‘And then it was our paternal aunt Karin.’
‘Oh! That’s no problem.’ (lit.: that makes nothing)
ja dä lä aj väha gähtja-min makkar sarva-jd gilgi-n njuova-t aj
‘And then he is also checking a bit which reindeer bulls they should also slaughter.’
‘At which of the two places have you been?’
man mälgat li-j gu li-j hiejm-an, i-v mån diede
‘How far it was, when one was home, I don’t know’
d-a-t lä tjähppis båtsoj ja villges åjjve
‘It is a black reindeer and a white head.’
ja d-a-t lä årro-m hoj buorak giesse
‘And it has been a really good summer.’
‘That beautiful one can (speak) the Saami language.’ (referring to a girl)
lä huj tjábba d-a-t d-a-t lä jävvja
‘It is a quite beautiful one, it, it is a white reindeer.’ (referring to a reindeer)
buhtsu lä nav buojde ja tjábbe
‘The reindeer are so fat and beautiful.’
‘I kiss the more beautiful one.’ (referring to ‘beautiful girl’)
‘The reindeer were farthest away.’ (lit.: in the farthest one (place))
‘Sven is as old as Inger.’ (lit.: Sven is one old with Inger)
‘We two are the same age.’ (lit.: we are one old)
d-á-t lä vanj dä gajk vuorasu-mos dága-duvvu-m
‘This was probably the absolute oldest made.’
jå månnå aj mujhta-v gu li-v unna máná-tj
‘Yes, I also remember when I was a small child.’
ber akta bällge ja smáva gisstá d-á
‘only one thumb, and small gloves, these here’
d-á-t lä dåpe sin unna dåpá-tj-a sin
‘This is in the house, in the little house.’
‘And I saw a little lingonberry there.’
‘Did you see many long-leggers?’ (referring to moose)
ja dä vállda nijbe-v ja tjuolast nagin rägi-jt
‘And then one takes a knife and cuts some holes.’
mana tjasski-t d-a-jd åjvi-jd ja gajk-ajd duhku
‘Go throw those heads and all that over there.’
‘I don’t have any hair.’ (lit.: on me isn’t a single hair)
gu itji-j almatj dåbdå aktak almatji-jd
‘There is much meat.’ (lit.: meat is much)
‘There are many pieces of meat.’ (lit.: meat pieces are many)
gu li-jmä vuodja-m d-a-jna traktor-ijna Grållå-jn
‘We pulled those fish here with a sled.’
men d-u-t biehtse men åneka-tj ja gassa-k
‘But that pine tree over there, how short and thick!’
gokt li-j dánne giehtjav-låk jage maŋŋus
‘... how it was here seventy years ago.’
dä li-j del tjuojgada-m ja gådda-m nällja-låk-gakktse stalpe sájte-jna
‘Then he skied and slew forty-eight wolves with a spear.’
‘He lived in the nineteen-hundreds, at the beginning.’
ja dä lä njelj-át aprilla uddne
‘And it is the fourth of April today.’
‘And the third one then goes to Stutja.’ (referring to a fishing net)
‘You know, I shot my very first long-legger.’ (referring to a moose)
ja dä d-a tjåhken minne gu gillge gåddåli-t nagan juhtusa-v
‘And then they go together when they are going to kill some animal.’
månnå ja Jåssjå li-jmen ulgon siri-jd tjågge-min
‘Josh and I were picking blueberries outside.’
dale lä bar bievadak mij sudda muahtaga-v
‘Now it’s only the sun which melts the snow.’
tjävla-v valda-v ja dä tjaná-v virbme-v d-a-n tjävvla-j ja hålå-v raddna-j
‘I take the bobber and then I tie the net to that bobber and I say to my friend...’
ja dä maŋŋel dä vuolga Västeråsa-j
‘And then after that you’ll drive to Västerås.’
nå giehto nagina-v d-a-n Luoddauvre birra
‘Well then I say we should obviously go.’
‘Oh no, I’ll probably have to take off some clothes.’
nå gukte galga dåhkå ålli-t d-a-jna
‘Well how are you going to reach it with that?’
man ednag biejve galga danne årro-t
‘How many days are you going to be there?’
men mån le-v tjåjve-v ruhtaste-min ullgus tjådågo-v le-v tjadna-m tjiebote-n
‘But I am cutting out the stomach, I have knotted the esophagus in the neck.’
d-a lä jábma-m ber muv äddne=l viesso-min dále
‘They have died, only my mother is still living now.’
månnå ja Jåssjå li-jmen ulgon siri-jd tjågge-min
‘Josh and I were picking blueberries outside.’
mån i-v vasja lipsusi-jd ja daggari-jd vállde-t d-á-n muddo-n
‘I don’t feel like taking the rumen fat and stuff at this time.’
nå ittji-j Henning dä skihpá gu li-j nåv gållu-m
‘Well Henning didn’t get sick after he had been freezing like that.’
ja d-a-t lä etjaláhkaj dä d-a-t lij dal navte gårro-duvvu-m
‘And that is different as it has been sewn like that.’
men d-á buhtsu ij lä mierke-duvvu-m
‘But these reindeer have not been marked.’
men i-v l-am dä månnå del skålå-n giese-n
‘But I haven’t been in school during the summer.’
vieso-jmä vanj ganska buoragi-t d-a-jna guollemi-jn aj
‘We definitely lived pretty well with the fishing, too.’   Note that ganska is a nonce borrowing from language contactSwedish; cf.Swedish ganska ‘quite’.
buhtsu mielke-st ittj-in ber vuosta-jd dága
‘They didn’t only make cheese from reindeer milk.’
ja dä bedja d-u-n nubbe biele-n aj risi-jd
‘And then one puts twigs on the other side, too.’
gajk vuoras-umos saddje=l vanj d-á-t urru-m dulutji-st
‘This was definitely the absolute oldest place from the old days.’

‘and to cut meat into the coffee’
ja dä skåvlå-máná minni-n d-a-n bajel sparki-jin
‘And then the school children went over that by kick-sled.’
ja badde åst-o badde birra d-a-nne
så åtjo-jmä badjel nällje kronor tjilos dalloj
‘So we received more than four Swedish crowns per kilogram back then.’
d-á-jste åtjo-jmä mielke-v vuoja-v vuosta-v ja biergo-v
‘We got milk, butter, cheese and meat from these.’
buhtsu lä nav buojde ja tjábbe
‘The reindeer are so fat and beautiful.’
men mån jahka-v gu li-djiv mån akta-låk-nelldje jala akta-låk-vihta jáge
‘But I believe when I was fourteen or fifteen years (old)...’
‘Do you take coffee with or without sugar?’
ja dálasj ájge-n ij almatj aktak almatj danne vieso jala åro
‘And nowadays no one lives or resides there.’
ini-jmä eller båro-jmä siri-jd ja láddagi-jd
‘We had or ate blueberries and cloudberries.’

så dä måj mähti-jmen måj Jåsjå-jn mähti-jmen 14ptdä tjuäjjga-t d-á-n Stuor-njárga nalá

dä [virrte-n märrke-t]VC d-a-jt miesi-jd dále tjaktja-n
‘Then we have to mark those calves now in the autumn.’
‘One cannot really have too big of a fire.’
‘I have been able to speak Saami.’
‘There were so many reindeer.’ (lit.: ‘so much reindeer’)
‘And the third one is then placed at Stutja.’ (referring to ‘fishing net’)
‘That beautiful one can speak the Saami language.’
d-á lä jisse [gistá me-jd dálve-n gallga adne-t]NP
‘These are gloves which one has in winter.’
‘I believe I went in the summer.’
‘And Henning had been home for a week.’
‘They themselves of course had milk and cheese.’

‘And it has been a really good summer.’
‘You know, I shot my very first long-legger.’

‘If one slaughtered them correctly, then one would take them out before one hung them up.’
‘At that time it was, it went well.’
vieso-jmä vanj [[ganska]AdvP1 buoragi-t]AdvP2 d-a-jna guollemi-jn aj
‘We definitely lived quite well with the fishing, too.’
‘But this one is obviously quite old.’
‘I am standing on ‘Big Point’ in Västerfjäll.’
‘I have to put water into that.’
dä Kataridna ja månnå [d-a-n gierge nanne]PP pruvko-jin ståhkå-t
‘Katarina and I used to play on that rock.’
dä almatj bieja-j rise-v dále nåvte
‘Then one places the stick like this.’
ja d-á-v aj mån vuojna-v vindege-st muv dåbe-st
‘And I also see this from the window from my house.’
‘The man gives the flower to the woman.’
‘First I’ll put out the net in Áktjuotjålbme.’
‘(The reindeer herder) will pull (the reindeer buck) out.’

‘He grilled them then on a stick.’
‘And there I saw a little lingonberry.’
‘I think (the mouse) had a pantry there.’
d-á-t lä vanj dä gajk vuorasu-mos dága-duvvu-m
‘This was probably the absolute oldest made.’
‘The hut has been built by children.’
‘The Saami keep the reindeer there in the summer.’
‘One puts out fishing nets in the evening.’
‘There is sorrel in the mountains, too.’ (lit.: there are sorrels...)
motora vadnasi-j motora ij gävdnu sáme giela-n
‘...with motor boats. There is no (word for) “motor” in the Saami language.’
buhtsoj lä nav buojde ja tjábbe
‘The reindeer are so fat and beautiful.’
‘You all may drink water from that.’
ja dä del virrti-n allge-t bäbbma-t
‘And then they had to start to feed (the reindeer).’
‘We can speak the Pite Saami language.’
dä i-j del almatj sida nagin sadjá-j vuällge-t
‘Then one obviously doesn’t want to go anywhere.’
jo da lä akta vuoberis gallga giesse-t ulgus
‘Yes, it’s a 3-year old reindeer buck, (he) will pull (it) out.’   Specifically, a vuoberis is a three-year-old reindeer buck, but the gloss has been shortened to save space.
jus galga sáme vieso-v vallde-t dä galga mielaga-v dal navt rutasti-t
‘If I choose Saami style, then I will pull the sternum like this.’
lä dån manna-m nagin bále ja tjuvvu-m Visteg-ij
‘Have you ever gone and accompanied (them) to Vistek?’
men mån le-v tjåjve-v ruhtaste-min ullgus
‘There wasn’t any butter to buy at all.’
men ijtji-n del bårå d-a-n sisste
‘But they didn’t eat out of this.’
ij vanj dä máhte ilá stuor dålå-v adne-t
‘But you can’t have too big of a fire.’
dä i-v lä åbbå gulla-m d-a-v
nej mån i-v lä bårrå-m men Jåssjå=l bårrå-m
‘No, I haven’t eaten (it), but Josh has eaten (it).’
‘How long do you have those in the smoke hole for?’
nå gukte li-j Áhkabákte-n gu dånnå lidje mánná
‘Well what was Áhkkabákkte like when you were a child?’
li-j sån uktu jala li-j Halvar aj maŋŋen
‘Was he alone or was Halvar also along?’
‘Were you allowed to speak Saami there?’
‘Well then I say we really should probably go.’
‘Oh no, I’ll probably have to take off some clothes.’
men ijtji-n del bårå d-a-n siste men edne-n biebmo-jd biergo-jd ja dále návte deggara sinne
‘But they obviously didn’t eat out of that, but they had food, meat and so on in such things.’
dále=l gámbal dåhpe jala almatj hållå unna dåbá-tj
‘Now this is the old house, or one says “the little house”.’
ja dä mån hålå-v att sida-v bajke-t
‘And then I say that I want to poop.’
men mån dieda-v att háre lä jávre-n
‘But I know that there are greyling in the lake.’
mån jáhka-v stuor tjuovtj-a lä danne
‘I believe there are big whitefish there.’
men mån tuhtji-v d-a-t lij nav suohtas tielta-jn viesso-t
‘But I think it was so nice to stay in tents.’
‘But then I say we shot a moose.’
mån i-v diede gåsse gillgi-n gávnadi-t maŋe-p bále
‘I don’t know when we’ll meet next time.’
mån i-v skene ma-v dån hålå
man mälgat li-j gu li-j hiejma-n i-v mån diede
‘I don’t know how far it was to get home.’
nå gosse dijá älgi-jdä Örnvika-st vuodje-t vadnása-v
‘Well when did you start to take the boat from Örnvik?’
ja dä del virrti-n allge-t biebma-t fodderi-jd vuodje-t
‘And so they obviously had to start to feed, to transport the feed.’
nä mån li-v åjaldahta-m vallde-t maŋen
‘No, I forgot to take it along.’
‘I am forgetting to say, when I did the perch...’
hihtu vanj dä baktja-t innan mån stärti-v motora-v
‘Well you have to back up then before I start the motor.’
gu lidji-n sladji-m dä båhti-n d-a bajás
‘Once (the farmers) had harvested, then they (the plants) came up.’
dä ini-jmä akta-v vuoksa-v ma-jna vuojadi-jmä muora-jd
‘We had one bull with which we transported firewood.’
ja dä maŋŋe-mus skoteri-jd ma-jd ini-ga
‘...and the last snowmobiles which they had.’
dä lä ájge ma lä urru-m
‘Those are times which have been.’ (i.e.: ‘those were the good old days’)
dä li-n nuora álmatj-a ma li-n riejdnohi-men
‘They were young people who were herding.’
d-a-t li-j duv gugu ma-sa båhte-n
d-a-t lä náhppe ma-n sisa båhtje-n buhtsu-jd
‘This is a milking bowl into which they milked reindeer.’
men dä lä danne urru-m d-a-t pluovve ma-n namma lä mij lä namma d-a-n d-á-v mijá Árjepluove-v
‘But here was the pond whose name was, which was the name of that, this, our Arjeplog.’
